Janet,

The Federal Lands are not owned by the People, they are held in trust for the People. There is a world of difference in those words. We own nothing of them as any that visit them without first paying or paying and obtaining a permit will discover. Some are outside the Publics ability to visit under any circumstance, only the well connected or the Government Employee may visit them. How much of the country should be restricted from public access and why should those that pay taxes to the Government that holds the land in their name be charged to visit it?

As Ross Douthat is beginning to do now, Richard Luettgen, you too need to begin to construct a narrative that explains why your man and your party did not win as you have long proclaimed they would.  I look forward to your posts on November 7, but couldn't you give us all a hint now on the scenario you plan to use?

The extra $1 we put in every week for our kids for charity is a dollar they would not have received in pocket money, so for them it is a way of getting a say over some of the family's overall contributions to charities, rather than a way of forcing them to use their own money.

So far they have mostly opted to give to animal shelters. In one case they gave to a collection at their school for children in Haiti. We have never told them where to donate.

We also believe it is a way for them to learn to appreciate that we are fortunate compared to many other people (and animals) in this world and to show some care and compassion for those less fortunate.

I don't buy the comparison to your employer. I am not my children's employer. I am their parent. It is my job to teach them moral values. That is not your employer's job. Unlike employers I "force" them to do lots of things (homework, going to bed at night, take showers, clean their room), so I am not to worried about "forcing" them to make charitable contributions.

I must have missed the "so many times" that stagnant wages have been mentioned as a cause of the current economic stress.

I absolutely agree with you and have wondered why we aren't all rallying around an big increase in the minimum wage. Corporations, including the likes of Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs, are flush with money precisely because the increase in labor productivity that produced the abundance of capital (much of which went chasing after mortgage investments) was not equitabily distributed to the workers who produced the wealth. Had labor unions retained their strength, increased wages would have been on the table during every labor contract negotiation. As is, we had no one fighting for us.

Our politics has gone from being each having his own opinion, to each having his own facts. We cannot have a debate on how much we should do to mitigate global warming, if half or more of the electorate denies that global warming is happening, let alone is a threat.

When the free market has failed in contains the costs of health care for young adults and families, no one in the reality based community can advocate a market solution for the health care of our seniors. Yet we are stampeded with Death Panel rhetoric.

We cannot fight two wars and pay for them with a tax cut - but that we could was the dominant ideology of the first decade of this century.

As has been pointed out so many times even in the pages of this newspaper, if wages had kept pace with the economy's rising productivity, the median income would be $90K instead of the current stagnant-for-a-generation $50K.

So, let us sacrifice, starting with the blinders we wear.

Lincoln was not the least bit ambivalent about slavery. He introduced a bill for DC emancipation already as a Congressman in 1848. AS he wrote in 1864, "If slavery is not wrong, nothing is wrong. I can not remember when I did not so think, and feel. And yet I have never understood that the Presidency conferred upon me an unrestricted right to act officially upon this judgment and feeling." He did not believe he had the constitutional right to abolish slavery, except as a war measure (or through a constitutional amendment, which he strongly pushed). But the Unionist coalition was considerably larger than the antislavery or abolitionist coalition. And Lincoln could not afford to alienate any Unionists at the outset of the war.

It is my fervent hope that, along with the "clear advantage on national security policy," President Obama, like our Chairman of the Federal Reserve, has gained a new understanding and reached new conclusions about what it is that must be done with our economy the instant the election is decided, and who to appoint to Treasury to carry it out.

It isn't just Greece that we must be weary about, but all of Europe. The demands exacted from Spain and Portugal by the Germans are sheer folly. Soon, the educated young of these two countries will do the same as their Greek counterparts and leave for jobs elsewhere. According to published reports, the unemployment rate in Spain for educated young people under age 26 is 50%. Austerity is the very last thing these countries need. President Obama, of the two candidates running for president, is the only one who has the breadth of knowledge and intellectual flexibility to lead Europe back from the brink of repeating not so distant history. Mr. Romney would only encourage the kind of savage austerity the Germans are now pushing. Such encouragement will precipitate a third world war.

Here at home, we should be thankful for the inadequate stimulus Obama did get to implement. It is thanks to it that we are in much better shape than our European counterparts. In hindsight, we should have done a lot more.

Mitt Romney has made himself so unattractive that it's highly unlikely he can win. His loss will truly be our salvation.

I don't recall my sibling or me receiving allowances. We had to help around the house, but I wouldn't say we had to do a lot of chores. We were in 4H and showed livestock at the county fair; we were allowed to keep the money from selling the livestock, but it was put into savings accounts. I started babysitting when I was around 12, I suppose. I detasselled corn one summer (the worst!) and as soon as I was old enough I took the training to become a lifeguard, which was my summer job throughout high school. (Fourteen is *not* too young for a "real job"!) During the school year, since the pool wasn't open, my parents would give me money if I asked, but I would also babysit. (There weren't many job opportunities in my population 800 hometown, especially if you weren't old enough to drive.)

In college, my parents paid for the half of my tuition that was not covered by my scholarship; the money I earned from my work study job (lifeguarding) was mine to spend as I wished so I never needed to ask them for money for clothes, gas, entertainment, etc. I've always been a saver so, despite living in an expensive city and working in nonprofits, I've been able to live credit card debt free, save for my retirement, and amass a decent "rainy day fund."

Carter did not call for "just sacrifice."  He asked all Americans to endure the discomfort that energy conservation might cause so that we would not be dependent on foreign oil, and thus not invloved in foreign wars.  Energy independece was the "something" worthy of the sacrifice.  Had we Americans heeded his advice, we would have had no reason to invade Iraq.  President Carter is the president we all like to flog, but he was a prescient and wise man, even though he was politically inept.

We follow your save/spend/give philosophy with our kids' allowances too and have found that this creates (a) a regular opportunity to discuss choices, (b) a way to practice spending money that teaches early lessons about good and bad decisions, (c) an opportunity to see savings accumulate fast, and (d) an opportunity to talk about why giving to others important, especially if your alternative for that dollar is a pack of gum or other trivial purchase. Ross Douthat's column today is, I believe, a sign of the times.  Conservative pundits are constructing narratives that will explain the anticipated Republican failure at the polls this November in ways that remove all responsibility from the bankruptcy of Republican policies or the failure of the party to produce a viable candidate.  Douthat seems to think we American voters are in a stupor, a sort of economic shell shock that is preventing us from aspiring to anything more than this dreadful economic state.  We are the proverbial frog that is slowly boiling to death.  This has nothing to do, of course, with the Romney/Ryan disaster or the failure of Republican economic policy of low taxes and austerity.

Rationalexpectations -

If government spends more money, taxes go up. If it spends less money, taxes go down. Progressive tax policies help determine who pays those taxes. But the total amount of taxes is determined by the cost of the government services. If you raise one person's taxes, someone else will pay less.

There are two paths to redistribution which could gain wide approval if they were better publicized.

They both grow form the work of the late Louis Kelso, inventor of the Employee Stock Ownership Plan, presently used by 11,000 companies.

The first is what Kelso termed The Second Income Plan. This would open a practical means of ending poverty. It can provide substantial second incomes to almost the entire population without depending upon savings. See Second Incomes at www.aesopinstitute.org for a recent version.It can restore the American Dream.

The second can be found on the same site under the title: A New, New Deal. It uses well proven financial techniques that Kelso pioneered, to provide major amounts of new capital to grow the economy. It inherently redistributes wealth in the process, in a manner that is likely to be welcomed by most Americans.

Two other Paths to Abundance will be found on the same website.

All four taken together would open the prospect of dramatically reducing unemployment and rapidly regrowing the economy.
